quiz.title: Grade 12 Physics
quiz.subtitle: Unit 5, Quiz 2: Magnetic Force on Moving Charges
quiz.subject: Physics

questions.question: What is the formula for the magnetic force ($F_B$) acting on a charge $q$ moving with velocity $\vec{v}$ in a magnetic field $\vec{B}$?
questions.explanation: The magnetic force magnitude is given by $F = qvB\sin\theta$, where $\theta$ is the angle between $\vec{v}$ and $\vec{B}$. The force is maximum when $\vec{v} \perp \vec{B}$ ($\theta = 90^\circ$).

questions.question: If a proton is moving due East in a magnetic field directed straight down into the Earth, what is the direction of the force?
questions.explanation: Using the right-hand rule for positive charges: point fingers in direction of velocity (East), curl them toward magnetic field direction (down), thumb points in force direction (North). For protons (positive), force is North.

questions.question: A charged particle enters a uniform magnetic field at an angle of $0^\circ$ (parallel to the field). The resulting path of the particle is:
questions.explanation: When $\vec{v}$ is parallel to $\vec{B}$, $\theta = 0^\circ$, so $\sin\theta = 0$ and magnetic force $F = 0$. The particle continues with constant velocity in a straight line.

questions.question: What is the net Lorentz force on a charge $q$ that is moving through both an electric field $\vec{E}$ and a magnetic field $\vec{B}$?
questions.explanation: The complete Lorentz force is $\vec{F} = q(\vec{E} + \vec{v} \times \vec{B})$, combining both electric and magnetic forces on a moving charge.

questions.question: An electron and a proton enter a magnetic field with the same velocity perpendicular to the field. Which one will have a smaller orbital radius?
options: They will have the same radius.
questions.explanation: Radius $r = \frac{mv}{qB}$. The electron has much smaller mass ($m_e \approx 1/1836 \, m_p$) but same charge magnitude, so its radius is much smaller despite having the same speed.

questions.question: The magnetic force on a moving charge does zero work because:
options: The force is always parallel to the displacement.
The force is always perpendicular to the velocity.
The magnetic field has no energy.
questions.explanation: Magnetic force $\vec{F} = q\vec{v} \times \vec{B}$ is always perpendicular to velocity. Work $W = \vec{F} \cdot \vec{d}$ requires force component along displacement. Since $\vec{F} \perp \vec{v}$, no work is done and kinetic energy remains constant.

questions.question: If you double the speed of a particle and double the magnetic field strength, the magnetic force increases by a factor of:
questions.explanation: $F = qvB\sin\theta$. Doubling $v$ gives factor of 2, doubling $B$ gives factor of 2. Combined effect: $2 \times 2 = 4$.

questions.question: A particle enters a magnetic field at an angle of $45^\circ$. Its motion will be a combination of linear and circular motion, resulting in a:
questions.explanation: When velocity has components both perpendicular and parallel to $\vec{B}$, the perpendicular component causes circular motion, while the parallel component causes linear motion along the field. The combination is helical motion.

questions.question: Which device uses the balance of electric and magnetic forces to select particles of a specific speed?
questions.explanation: A velocity selector uses perpendicular $\vec{E}$ and $\vec{B}$ fields. When $qE = qvB$, net force is zero for particles with speed $v = E/B$. Only particles with this speed pass through undeflected.

questions.question: A $2.0\text{ C}$ charge moves at $10\text{ m/s}$ perpendicular to a $0.5\text{ T}$ field. What is the magnitude of the force?

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You have mastered the magnetic force on moving charges, including direction rules, path determination, and applications like velocity selectors.
scoreMessages.70: Very good! Solid understanding of magnetic forces. Review the right-hand rule for force direction and how velocity components relative to the field affect particle trajectories.
scoreMessages.50: Fair. Focus on: 1) The magnetic force formula $F = qvB\sin\theta$, 2) Using the right-hand rule for force direction, 3) Different paths (straight, circular, helical), 4) The Lorentz force combination.
scoreMessages.0: Start with the fundamentals: Review the magnetic force equation, practice the right-hand rule for different charge types, and understand why magnetic forces do no work.
